message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for patients with a past history of infective endocarditis. None of the other conditions listed require prophylaxis according to current guidelines.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent infective endocarditis is recommended only for patients with a past history of infective endocarditis, not for the other conditions listed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to the latest guidelines, antibiotic prophylaxis is only recommended for patients with a past history of infective endocarditis, not for the other options listed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Antibiotic prophylaxis is only recommended for patients with a past history of infective endocarditis, as well as those with certain congenital heart defects (such as unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease), cardiac valve disease, or a history of cardiac transplantation and with valvulopathy. None of the other options would warrant antibiotic prophylaxis for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only a past history of infective endocarditis would warrant antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent recurrence during the tooth extraction surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to the 2017 American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines, only patients with a past history of infective endocarditis require antibiotic prophylaxis before dental procedures. HOCM, VSD, and mitral regurgitation do not require antibiotic prophylaxis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The American Heart Association guidelines for antibiotic prophylaxis before dental procedures only apply to patients with a specific cardiac condition. Past history of infective endocarditis is one such condition, while HOCM, VSD, and mitral regurgitation do not warrant antibiotic prophylaxis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only a past history of infective endocarditis warrants antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent future infections during dental procedures. HOCM, VSD, and mitral regurgitation do not increase the risk of infective endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only a past history of infective endocarditis warrants antibiotic prophylaxis for dental procedures. HOCM and VSD are not listed by the American Heart Association as conditions that require prophylactic antibiotics. Mitral regurgitation is only recommended for prophylaxis if there is associated valve damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The American Heart Association recommends that antibiotic prophylaxis be given to patients with a past history of infective endocarditis before invasive dental procedures, but not for HOCM, VSD, or mitral regurgitation. Therefore, option (C) is the correct choice.
